ground_truth_answer: In-line sodium monitoring requires controlling hydrogen ion interference by raising the pH through adding ammonia gas or volatile amine, with temperature effects reduced through automatic compensation. The system is calibrated using known sodium concentration solutions. In contrast, Type T thermocouples (Copper/Constantan) are limited by copper oxidation to about 370°C, but they excel in low-temperature applications down to -200°C. The interference management approaches are fundamentally different - chemical adjustment for sodium monitoring versus material selection and temperature range limitations for Type T thermocouples.
